captions.text:
Where, is the European Union? Obviously here
somewhere, but much like the the European

continent itself, which has an unclear boundary,
the European Union also has some fuzzy edges
to it.

To start, the official members of the European
Union are, in decreasing order of population:

* Germany
* France

* The United Kingdom
* Italy

* Spain
* Poland

* Romania
* The Kingdom of the Netherlands

* Greece
* Belgium

* Portugal
* The Czech Republic

* Hungary
* Sweden

* Austria
* Bulgaria

* Denmark
* Slovakia

* Finland
* Ireland

* Croatia
* Lithuania

* Latvia
* Slovenia

* Estonia
* Cyprus

* Luxembourg
* Malta

The edges of the EU will probably continue
to expand further out as there are other countries
in various stages of trying to become a member.

How exactly the European Union works is hideously
complicated and a story for another time,

but for this video you need know only three
things:
1. Countries pay membership dues and
2. Vote on laws they all must follow and

3. Citizens of member countries are automatically
European Union citizens as well

This last means that if you're a citizen of
any of these countries you are free to live

and work or retire in any of the others. Which
is nice especially if you think your country

is too big or too small or too hot or too
cold. The European Union gives you options.

By the way, did you notice how all three of
these statements have asterisks attached to

this unhelpful footnote? Well, get used to
it: Europe loves asterisks that add exceptions
to complicated agreements.

These three, for example, point us toward
the first bit of border fuzziness with Norway,

Iceland and little Liechtenstein. None of
which are in the European Union but if you're

a EU citizen you can live in these countries
and Norwegians, Icelanders, or Liechtensteiner(in)s
can can live in yours.

Why? In exchange for the freedom of movement
of people they have to pay membership fees

to the European Union -- even though they
aren't a part of it and thus don't get a say
its laws that they still have to follow.

This arrangement is the European Economic
Area and it sounds like a terrible deal, were

it not for that asterisk which grants EEA
but not EU members a pass on some areas of

law notably farming and fishing -- something
a country like Iceland might care quite a
lot about running their own way.

Between the European Union and the European
Economic Area the continent looks mostly covered,

with the notable exception of Switzerland
who remains neutral and fiercely independent,

except for her participation in the Schengen
Area.

If you're from a country that keeps her borders
extremely clean and / or well-patrolled, the

Schengen Area is a bit mind-blowing because
it's an agreement between countries to take
a 'meh' approach to borders.

In the Schengen Area international boundaries
look like this: no border officers or passport

checks of any kind. You can walk from Lisbon
to Tallinn without identification or need
to answer the question: "business or pleasure?".

For Switzerland being part of Schengen but
not part of the European Union means that

non-swiss can check in any time they like,
but they can never stay.

This koombaya approach to borders isn't appreciated
by everyone in the EU: most loudly, the United

Kingdom and Ireland who argue that islands
are different. Thus to get onto these fair
isles, you'll need a passport and a good reason.

Britannia's reluctance to get fully involved
with the EU brings us to the next topic: money.

The European Union has its own fancy currency,
the Euro used by the majority, but not all

of the European Union members. This economic
union is called the Eurozone and to join a

country must first reach certain financial
goals -- and lying about reaching those goals
is certainly not something anyone would do.

Most of the non-Eurozone members when they
meet the goals, will ditch their local currency

in favor of the Euro but three of them Denmark,
Sweden and, of course, the United Kingdom,

have asterisks attracted to the Euro sections
of the treaty giving them a permanent out-out.

And weirdly, four tiny European countries
Andorra, San Marino, Monaco & Vatican City

have an asterisk giving them the reverse:
the right print and use Euros as their money,

despite not being in the European Union at
all.

So that's the big picture: there's the EU,
which makes all the rules, the Eurozone inside

it with a common currency, the European Economic
Area outside of it where people can move freely

and the selective Schengen, for countries
who think borders just aren't worth the hassle.

As you can see, there's some strange overlaps
with these borders, but we're not done talking

about complications by a long shot one again,
because empire.

So Portugal and Spain have islands from their
colonial days that they've never parted with:

these are the Madeira and Canary Islands are
off the coast of Africa and the Azores well

into the Atlantic. Because these islands are
Spanish and Portuguese they're part of the
European Union as well.

Adding a few islands to the EU's borders isn't
a big deal until you consider France: the

queen of not-letting go. She still holds onto
a bunch of islands in the Caribbean, Reunion

off the coast of Madagascar and French Guiana
in South America. As far as France is concerned,

these are France too, which single handedly
extends the edge-to-edge distance of the European
Union across a third of Earth's circumference.

Collectively, these bits of France, Spain
and Portugal are called the Outermost Regions

-- and they're the result of the simple answer
to empire: just keep it.

On the other hand, there's the United Kingdom,
the master of maintaining complicated relationships

with her quasi-former lands -- and she's by
no means alone in this on such an empire-happy
continent.

The Netherlands and Denmark and France (again)
all have what the European Union calls Overseas

Territories: they're not part of the European
Union, instead they're a bottomless well of

asterisks due to their complicated relationships
with both with the European Union and their

associated countries which makes it hard to
say anything meaningful about them as a group
but...

in general European Union law doesn't apply
to these places, though in general the people

who live there are European Union citizens
because in general they have the citizenship

of their associated country, so in general
they can live anywhere in the EU they want

but in general other European Union citizens
can't freely move to these territories.

Which makes these places a weird, semipermeable
membrane of the European Union proper and

the final part we're going to talk about in
detail even though there are still many, more

one-off asterisks you might stumble upon,
such as: the Isle of Man or those Spanish

Cities in North Africa or Gibraltar, who pretends
to be part of Southwest England sometimes,

or that region in Greece where it's totally
legal to ban women, or Saba & friends who

are part of the Netherlands and so should
be part of the EU, but aren't, or the Faeroe

Islands upon which while citizens of Denmark
live they lose their EU citizenship, and on
and on it goes.

These asterisks almost never end, but this
video must.

comments.text:
It's frightening to see so many pro-EU people. It's like you people 
completely ignore the cries of your fellow citizens, because BBC or The 
Guardian told you too, and I don't blame any of you, really. But honestly, 
think for a second. Is the EU really that great for you? The euro has 
failed southern Europe, the free movement of people is a ridiculous 
concept, the open border policy is insane, and the lack of self-governance 
is just insulting. And do you people think you can turn an entire 
continent, each with unique, and colorful history, languages, culture, etc, 
into some Confederate pseudo-national conglomerate? Why do you want that? 
On top of that, you think, in an attempt to erase national identity, you 
can shove multiculturalism down the throats of your fellow citizens? I 
understand that many of you are probably teenagers, who are well off, and 
haven't experienced/seen the negative effects of this experiment, but if 
you did for whatever reason protest, they would simply brush you off, 
because they don't care what you think either way. You would see that The 
EU would eat up all of Europe, Russia, China, and maybe even fucking Africa 
if it could, and any protests would be meaningless at that point.
The only people who's best interests are in the EU, are the EU powers that 
be, so of course they're going to fight to keep this organization up and 
running.  
Europe is not the fucking United States of America, and the idea of 
striving to be such a thing shouldn't even be entertained.﻿

Hello Internet! Greek here! 

Couple of things: 

1) All the stuff happening in Greece, 100% our fault. Sometimes Greeks say 
stuff like: "If only the rules were tougher when we joined, and the 
Eurozone rules are to blame, and If only Europe helped more" and it comes 
out as: "It's Europes fault" or even worse "It's Germanys fault" That is 
very unfortunate. Also, it is not the case at all.

2) This whole deal about "Lying to enter the Eurozone", it's not like 
11.000.000 people knew about it and lied to every single one of you. No. It 
was EU and Greek officials (Unelected officials in Greeces National Bank to 
be precise) that did the coocking of the books, and they lied to us Greeks 
as well... Just keep that in mind please...

3) I know some of you are kind of unhappy with the new Greek goverment, but 
could you please not? For one, this goverment isn't the same people who 
lied to you all these years, and you should be glad for that. Then, let me 
tell you how much of a delightful change they are. They may not look the 
part, but they were very effective in the past 2 months in domestic 
matters. Just cut them some slag. They have to deal with a domestic 
humanitarian crisis, a huge wave of immigrants from war torn countries, a 
great depression, and have external pressure at the same time...

So... That's all. Greetings from Greece ^_^﻿

comments.text:
The funniest part about this video isn't the fact that it's factually 
incorrect and blatant propaganda, it's the people in the comment section 
going on about how much they love Europe, its peoples and how it should 
unite because it would become such a powerhouse.
But then they also have a certain stance which contradicts everything else 
they believe in: They want all white people to be exterminated and white 
peoples lands settled by non-whites. Why? Because they've been brainwashed 
since youth to believe this is a positive thing.

I hope you retards will one day realise that your ancestors fought, bled 
and died to create this civilization FOR US, defending it FROM THEM. To be 
the first of your line to spread your legs for foreigners and open your 
door for invaders, such a waste, such a shame. All generations past look 
down on you.﻿

comments.author: СтараСрбија

comments.text:
+Daniel Injic Yeah. Bihać is not the only place in Bosnia seriously 
connected to mediëval Croatia. But I didn't say Bihać was the only place in 
Bosnia connected to Croatia. With Bihać I meant a bigger piece of western 
Bosnia. I forgot Bihać was that close to the Croatian border :P.  I 
should've known, cause I've been pretty close to that area. I still made a 
mistake with how big that piece of Croatian Bosnia was. However, the core 
of medieval Croatia would still only be a bit more east of Bihać. I would 
say between Bosanska Krupa and Prijedor. The map you showed was more or 
less Croatia at its biggest extent. This is why Bosnia is not all that 
important to Croatia. Only the west. Places like Brčko, Sarajevo and Tuzla 
were not that important. Even if Vrhbosna was founded by Croatians (you 
have a (short) reliable article?). 
About Duvno/Tomislavgrad. Altough there's no clear definition, I wouldn't 
say this is a town in Hercegovina. My personal definition of 
Hercegovina: The Drainage basins of the Neretva and the Trebišnjica. At 
least I wouldn't say Duvno/Tomislavgrad is deep (like you say) in 
Hercegovina. You could say that one part of Hercegovina had been important 
to Croatia (west) whereas another part barely had any importance 
(east). The eastern parts (around Trebinje) weren't that important to 
Croatia.
I also have to point out one of your sentences:
"A small part of Bosnia was independent for a short time before the 
Ottomans conquered it.''
I do not completely agree with this. It was not that small. The last 150 
years of its existence it covered much of current Bosnia. The Bosnian 
Kingdom also existed for a few centuries. I wouldn't call it ''short 
time''. 
I do agree with your opinion about ultranationalists. I'm a bit a 
nationalist myself. I have my ideas about how some borders should be (based 
on history and the demographics (and its history)), but they never go that 
far as these people and I'm still in favor of peaceful cooperation between 
peoples. These ultranationalists never consider looking it from another 
point of view.
About the years of suffering from Serb ultranationalism. So this actually 
means the 35 years of Serb ultranationalism in Kosovo weren't 35 years. The 
Albanians weren't that mistreated just after Tito's dead (first years) and 
Kosovo had already gained its ''independence'' in 2008,. So it would be 
more reasonable to say it was like 15 years.
About that question of yours. I think (I unfortunately don't know much 
about them gaining independence in 2008) Serbia couldn't do much against 
NATO intervention. NATO was stronger. It would be a lost case. 
Back to the beginning of your comment. You're welcome ;). I never do stuff 
like that in my comments. I only do it when they really pissed me off. When 
they're asking for it. But then I'm still trying not to do it. I respect 
people as long as they respect me. I had lots of discussions with for 
example Albanians. They also do stuff like that. However, there's one thing 
they've never done to me on YouTube. And a few Americans did it. They gave 
me some deaththreats. They are probably just bluffing, cause they were 
pissed, but it looks like Albanian nationalists deserve more respect than 
American nationalists.
comments.author: Rex Brandsma

comments.text:
+Rex Brandsma First of all, I would like to thank you for your kind, calm 
and factful reply. Many people insulted and attacked me verbally when I 
tried to explain them some things about Croatia and Serbia. That's why I 
thank you for your kindness and I respect that.

Now back to the main stuff.
Bosnia was the core of Croatian history alright. You've missed a couple of 
hundred years if you think that the area around Bihać is the only area 
connected to Croatia. 
This is all going to sound like "things which only a Croatian dude would 
say", but these things I'm going to say to you are legit and 100% true. I'm 
not a liar, I only deal with true facts from Internatonal history 
organizations (Wikipedia isn't too trustworthy).

The first independend Croatian state was established in the 800's and it 
was consisted of Red Croatia (a wide area around todays Zagreb), Dalmatia 
(85% of todays Croatian Dalmatia, together with Dubrovnik), Slavonia 
(without Srijem) and a big part of Bosnia (together with Herzegowina even 
though Herc. as a region didn't exist in that time).
In 925 the first Croatian kingdom was established with King Tomislav 
crowned in Duvno (croatian Duvanjsko Polje), today Tomislavgrad. Duvno is 
deep in Herzegowina today and in that time, almost whole Bosnia was 
Croatian.
Map of Croatia in 925: 
http://hr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kralj_Tomislav#/media/File:Tomislavova_Hrvatska.jpg

Bosnia was under Croatia for almost 600 years since the arrival of Croats 
in the 7th century. Croatia completely lost Bosnia when the Ottomans 
started conquering the whole Eastern and Southeastern Europe in the 15th 
century. (A small part of Bosnia was independent for a short time before 
the Ottomans conquered it).

Believe it or not, Sarajevo was first a Croatian city called Vrhbosna. When 
the Ottomans demolished that city, they established their own city on the 
area of Vrhbosna and called it Sarajevo in the 16th century.

Bosnia is related to Croatia more than any other country (except for the 
Turks because of Islam etc.)

Today, Bosnia doesn't belong to Croatia and Croatia doesn't claim Bosnia as 
a part of Croatia because it's a totally different situation and time today 
than back then.

The ultranationalist and extreme nationalist are in minority in Croatia, 
Bosnia and Serbia and they all are a bunch of uninformed people with a 
cabbage instead of a brain.

By ''40 years of Serb ultranationalism'', I meant the time from the death 
of Tito in 1980. (35 years from now, not 40, sorry for that). Even though 
Tito was "glorious" back in that time, he was indeed the only one who could 
hold the whole Yugoslavia as one. When he died, the Serbian 
ultranationalist started overtaking the country because they were the 
majority in the League of Communists of Yugoslavia (all 6 communist parties 
in one League) while Croats and Slovenians preffered a more federal type of 
Yugoslavia (which was rejected by the Serbs). 


For the '90% of Albanians in Kosovo' thing, I must admit that you're right. 
I haven't thought about it that way. But one question remains. I know that 
it was different back then in the 90's, but why didn't Serbia intervene 
militarily in 2008? The only answer I get in my head is that it would start 
an another war, but not between Serbia and the Kosovars, but between Serbia 
and Albania.
comments.author: Daniel Injic

comments.text:
+Daniel Injic I wouldn't say Bosnia used to be the core of Croatia. 
Maybe the region around Bihać, but I think that would rather be something 
like Velebit. But still. I think there is not that much difference other 
than religion. There used to be Croatians, Serbians and Bosnians in 
history with their own lands, but it's not that simple. I don't know 
exactly how to explain, but the fact is, that there is no real boundary 
between you people other than your religion. History is too messed up to 
give all Croatians one Croat history without the Serbs and Bosnians. I 
think a Croat from Dubrovnik shares a lot more (history, genetics and 
such) with a Serb from Trebinje than with another Croat from for example 
Split. A Croat from Mostar shares a lot more (history) with a Bosniak from 
Mostar than with a Croat from for example Dubrovnik. The thing I want to 
make clear is that Serbo-Croats in the former Yugoslavia define themselves 
with religion, but in some cases, that's actually the only difference!
There are also people who say Bosnia belongs to Croatia. I once saw a Croat 
with a tattoo of Greater Croatia (roughly Croatia with Bosnia). These are 
extreme nationalists, but there are always people with these kinds of 
extreme nationalistic ideas.
I was wondering what you meant by ''40 years of Serb ultranationalism''. 
Which years. Did you include the years of the Yugoslav Kingdom? It can't be 
the years of communist Yugoslavia.
Further on I also want you to know that the percentage of 90% Albanians in 
Kosovo mean nothing to me. They gained this number after their 
''independence''. About 150 years before this ''independence'' Serbs were 
(if you look at the demographic history of Kosovo) probably the majority. 
You might say Albanians suffered, but there number dramatically increased 
the last 300 years. And the remained Serbs certainly suffered after 
the ''independence''. A hated minority. Dicrimination and probably 
murdering as a result. There was also many heritage destroyed. Some of it 
was World Heritage. Churches and monasteries. What about the illegal Organ 
Trafficking? Confirmed by the UN.
comments.author: Rex Brandsma

comments.text:
+Rex Brandsma Kosovo was the core of Serbian history and the mainland of 
the first Serbs which came in the 8th century, but right now the Albanians 
are the majority there and they want to establish their own country by 
force. Im aware of everything what happens around me and I know that Kosovo 
is the core of the Serbian history. 
But today, the situation is different. Just like Kosovo WAS the core of 
Serbian history, Bosnia was the core of Croatian history. But you don't see 
people screaming "Bosnia is Croatia", do you? 
I don't think that you can call 40 years of Serbian ultranationalism over 
Albanians "nationalism for a few years". 
Ever since Tito died, every single ex-yugoslavian country except for Serbia 
suffered because of the "Greater Serbia ideology". 
I could explain everything to you how, what and why all this happened but 
it would take too much time to write and explain.
The point i tried to make is- 90% of Kosovo right now are Albanians. The 
country is practically an illegal state, but I don't think that you can 
call the massacre in Kosovar Mitrovica "Serbian suffering" because they did 
the massacre, not Kosovars. Thats the reason why Kosovo will probably sue 
Serbia for genocide. 
Check wikipedia and read about Ovcara massacre, Borovo Selo, Srebrenica 
massacre etc. 
Live and let live.
comments.author: Daniel Injic

comments.text:
+СтараСрбија Oh my fcking god. How the fuck are you so ignorant and why do 
you keep writting stuff that aren't true? Do you even listen to yourself?
You're obviously living in a serbian propaganda with 0 knowledge of your 
own history or the history of surrounding countries.
This is the last time i'm explaining things to you and I won't reply 
anymore on your replies (you're not older than 15 for sure). 
1st- Not over one million, not one million, not 700,000, not 100,000.
In the Jasenovac concentration camp were ~85,000 people killed by the Nazis 
and Ustashe. That's the only black mark in Croatian history and Croatia is 
well aware of that massacre. Even though that massacre was a thing of the 
Ustashe (which were mainly Croats), Croatia mourns over the victims of 
Jasenovac.
Don't try to write untrue stuff about the victims because it's already 
stated by the Simon Wiesenthal Centre and United States Holocaust Memorial 
Museum that Serbs are trying to enlarge (with untrue facts) the guilt of 
Croats because of the Jasenovac massacre.
Yes, the Ustashe were MAINLY Croats, but in the Jasenovac massacre were 
even the Serbian Chetniks involved. What can you say about that?

2nd- 80% of Croats were against the Ustashe ultranationalist group. 
Croats were not the ones who killed Serbs, Jews, Croats etc.
Ustashe and Nazis killed them.
Not Croats.
Ustashe and Nazis.
Get it now?

It's a pitty that Serbia has to write, tell and say untrue things about

years. 
Let me tell you one interesting fact. If you think that Serbia is so

Serbia is rapidly dissoluting because of all the bad things they did in the
